Graphical abstract Bulk spinel Co3O4 oxide and supported Co3O4 catalysts (Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2) were synthesized by one-step hydrothermal method. Their physicochemical properties were characterized by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy, N2-sorption, powder X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.These characterization strategies were applied to corroborate and better understand the interaction between Co3O4 and the supports induced by the synergistic effect of support and the subsequent catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. The catalytic stability was evaluated by three consecutive runs and a long-term test. A highest toluene catalytic activity was achieved over Co3O4/YSZ supported catalyst comparing to that of the bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts, which could be attributed to its better low-temperature reducibility, oxygen activation and mobility induced by the intrinsic support properties. Thus, the positive interaction between spinel Co3O4 phase and YSZ support promoted the intrinsic catalytic properties for toluene oxidation, which was verify by testing a dual catalyst bed system consisting of bulk Co3O4 catalyst and YSZ support beds. These results were further confirmed by temperature-programmed oxygen isotopic exchange experiments, which indicated that the activation and diffusion of oxygen species on the YSZ oxygen vacancy sites were promoted by Co3O4, resulting in a significant increase of the reaction rate for toluene oxidation. Keywords Bulk Co3O4 Synergistic effect of support TiO2 YSZ Toluene Oxidation Isotopic exchange 1 Introduction During the past decades, public attraction has been drawn on emission control of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Their release is linked to the increase of photochemical smog and atmospheric ozone, which could cause great harm to the environment and human health. VOCs is a widely ranging class of chemicals, commonly existing in many commercial waste streams and containing over three hundred compounds. Toluene is one of the most common and toxic VOCs, which needs to be abated by developing a clean technology. Heterogeneous catalytic oxidation is regarded as one of the most promising methods to remove kinds of VOCs with low energy consumption and high selective conversion into harmless products (CO2 and H2O) [1–3]. Cobalt oxides have been applied in many fields, such as high-performance lithium-ion batteries, gas sensors, supercapacitor electrode and so on [4–8]. Particularly, due to the low cost, remarkable catalytic performance, and excellent stability in different reactions, cobalt oxides are greatly applied in heterogeneous catalytic process like diesel soot combustion, NOx removal, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, reforming reaction, hydrogenation and many oxidation reactions [9–22]. In our previous work [23], it has been demonstrated that the cobalt oxides presented a high catalytic activity for vinyl chloride oxidation, which was correlated with the tunable morphology of Co3O4 nanocrystals. It was found that the catalytic activity and stability of cube-shaped Co3O4 catalyst was higher than that of sphere-shaped Co3O4 catalyst in the oxidation of vinyl chloride. This cube morphology was traduced in an enhanced amount of surface Co2+ and adsorbed oxygen active sites, which were finally the responsible of the above-mentioned higher activity. Moreover, recently supported catalysts have been widely researched in order to improve the catalytic performance by modifying the physicochemical properties of bare oxides with the introduction of the supports. The structural properties of the support can make significant impact on catalyst properties and performances, including reducibility, surface acidity, catalytic activity and stability [12,24–29]. Zhu and co-workers [12] synthesized a series of ZSM-5 supported Co3O4 catalysts together with bulk cobalt oxide. The ZSM-5 supported Co3O4 catalysts exhibited much better performance than bulk cobalt oxide catalyst, which was attributed to the easy reducibility of Co3+, the higher amount of surface lattice oxygen and the fast migration of oxygen ions into the lattice of cobalt oxide. Ousmane and co-workers [25] deposited gold particles on four different kinds of supports to prepare Au-supported catalysts and applied them in the abatement of propene and toluene. The interaction of gold nanoparticles with the support was spotlighted as an essential factor to enhance the catalytic performance of these catalysts. Therefore, understanding the support effects over bulk oxides is crucial, notably regarding the choice of an appropriate carrier material to improve the catalytic activity. For this propose, Co3O4 supported catalysts, using YSZ or TiO2 as a support, were synthetized by our previous one-step hydrothermal method in order to obtain a spinel cubic Co3O4 crystalline structure [23]. For this purpose, the oxide supports were directly introduced into the cobalt precursor solution, before starting the cobalt oxide crystallization. Toluene oxidation was chosen as a model reaction to evaluate their catalytic activity, noteworthy regarding the effect of YSZ or TiO2 supports. Therefore, the main aim of the present study was to evaluate the role of different supports on toluene catalytic oxidation reaction, stablishing the composition and catalytic activity relationship induced by the spinel Co3O4 phase and support synergistic combination. A standard set of characterization techniques, including X-ray diffraction, various spectroscopies and temperature programmed techniques, was used to evaluated catalyst physicochemical properties and to better understand the synergistic support effect. Three consecutive cycles and a long-term test were applied to test the stability of the catalysts. Furthermore, a powerful oxygen isotopic exchange technique was also carried out to get a better understanding of their catalytic behavior. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Bulk spinel cubic Co3O4 catalyst was prepared by hydrothermal process according to the literature with some modifications [23,30,31]. In brief, 8.73 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.30 g NaOH were dissolved in 30 mL H2O, respectively. Then, these two solutions were mixed and kept stirring for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed reactant was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and then heated at 180 °C for 5 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the obtained product was washed with ethanol and distilled water for several times and further dried at 60 °C. It was further calcined at 500 °C for 3 h in air to get the final product of Co3O4. The hydrothermal process was also applied in the preparation of spinel Co3O4-supported catalysts, where the amount of the precursors were the same as those used for bulk Co3O4 catalyst. Co(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH were dissolved in H2O. The solution was maintained at room temperature for 30 min under stirring. Subsequently, the calcined support was slowly added into the stirring solution with the calculated amount to obtain 20 wt.% Co3O4 (approximately 15 wt.% Co) in the Co3O4-supported catalysts. Then, this solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for catalyst hydrothermal synthesis. The hydrothermal, washing and drying procedures were the same than that used for bulk Co3O4 catalyst preparation. The supports used in this work were: TiO2 (DT-51, Millennium Inorganic Chemicals) and YSZ (8 mol% Y2O3-stabilized ZrO2, TOSOH). These commercial supports were pre-calcined at 500 °C under air atmosphere for 3 h before starting the hydrothermal synthesis. The final catalysts were denoted as Co3O4/TiO2 and Co3O4/YSZ. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The Co content of the catalyst was measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES) from HORIBA Jobin Yvon Activa equipped with a CCD detector. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were measured using a Bruker D5005 diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm). The scan range was from 10 to 80° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02° at a scanning speed of 2 s∙step−1. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 surface area and porosity analyzer after pre-desorption at 200 °C for 5 h. The specific surface area of each catalyst was calculated from the linear part according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Hydrogen Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were performed to measure the reducibility of the catalysts on Micromeritics AutoChem HP 2950 apparatus. 0.15 g sample was placed in a quartz reactor and flowed over by the reducing gas (20 vol% H2/Ar) with a flow rate of 30 mL∙min−1. The temperature range was from 25 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The water produced during the reduction was cooled down through a cold trap. The amount of H2 uptake in the process was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the analysis, the samples were pre-treated at 250 °C for 10 min with a gas flow of O2/He. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observations of the catalysts were performed on a JSM-7800F microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations of the catalysts were performed on a JEOL 2010 LaB6. The specimen for TEM was prepared by grinding the catalyst into powder in a mortar, dispersing it in ethanol and placing a droplet of the suspension onto a copper grid coated with carbon. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a commercial Ultra-DLD (Kratos analytical) photo-electron spectrometer using a monochromatized Al Kα (1486.6 eV) source. The charge energy shift of the XPS spectra was corrected fixing the adventitious carbon C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement Catalytic oxidation of toluene was carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor (220 nm in length and 4 mm in internal diameter) at atmospheric pressure, using 0.10 g catalyst (except for bulk Co3O4 catalyst that the amount of catalyst was 0.02 g, mixed with 0.08 g silicon carbide (SiC) to keep the same amount of cobalt). Regardless of catalyst used, the 0.1 g of catalyst was subsequently mixed with SiC to avoid any hot spot, preserving the final height of the catalytic bed for bulk and supported catalysts.The catalytic reaction was carried out with a mixture of toluene (1000 ppm) and synthetic air (20 vol.% O2 / 80 vol.% N2) under a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The concentration of CO2 was analyzed by PerkinElmer Clarus 500 GC equipped with a TCD. The reaction temperature program was started from room temperature to 80ºC with an initial temperature ramp of 5 °C min−1. Then a 30 min plateau was set to stabilize the signal, followed by a second temperature ramp of 2 °C min−1 up to 450ºC. After the heating run, the catalytic activity was also tested during the cooling range with a ramp of 1 °C min−1. This sequence was repeated three times for all the catalysts. Furthermore, the catalytic stability was evaluated by long-term test for the supported catalysts. The conversion was calculated according to the following equation. Toluene Conversion (%) = [CO2]realtime/[CO2]theoretical*100 Where [CO2]realtime represented the real-time concentration of CO2 during the reaction, and [CO2]theoretical represented the theory concentration of CO2 for the total oxidation of toluene. 2.4 Oxygen isotopic exchange The oxygen isotopic exchange experiments were performed in a closed setup already described elsewhere [32,33]. A U-type reactor was placed in a closed recycle system which was connected on one side to a Pfeiffer Vacuum QMS 200 mass spectrometer for the monitoring of the gas phase composition, and the other side to a vacuum pump. A recycling pump placed in the system removed limitations due to gas-phase diffusion. Temperature programmed oxygen isotopic exchange (TPOIE) experiments were performed on 20 mg of catalysts. Samples were pretreated under pure 16O2 flow at 700 °C during 1 h prior to cooling down to either 200 °C and then evacuated for 30 min. A 55 mbar dose of pure 18O2 (Isotec, 99.9%) was then introduced in the system and the heterolytic exchange reaction started (18O2(g)+16O(s)→ 18O16O(g)+18O(s) simple exchange). The temperature was increased from 200 to 700 °C with a ramp rate of 2 °C min−1. Temporal evolution of the concentrations of 18O2, 18O16O, and 16O2 isotopomers was continuously followed by collecting every 3 s the m/z = 36, 34, and 32 values, respectively. The m/z = 28 value was also monitored to detect any possible leak in the system. The determination of the atomic fraction of 18O in the gas-phase (αg), the number of O atoms exchanged (Ne) were described elsewhere [32,34]. Typically: α g = P 36 + 1 2 P 34 P 36 + P 34 + P 32 where P36, P34, and P32 are the partial pressures of 18O2, 18O16O, and 16O2 respectively, N e = N g * ( 1 - α g ) with Ng the number of 18O atoms in gas-phase at the beginning of the reaction. 3 Results and discussion The physico-chemical properties of the bulk Co3O4 and supported catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . The percentage of cobalt in bulk Co3O4 catalyst was 71% from the ICP-OES characterization, which was slightly lower than the expected value. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the catalysts was shown in Fig. 1 A. Both Co3O4 supported catalysts presented a profile of the type IV isotherm, showing a hysteresis loop due to capillary condensation representative of a porous material. The specific surface area (SSA) of bulk Co3O4 catalyst was 5 m2 g−1. As expected, the Co3O4-supported catalysts showed higher SSA than the bulk one (11 and 47 m2 g−1 forCo3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts, respectively). These values are below the SSA values of bare supports but very close to additive SSA (0.2*SSA (raw Co3O4) + 0.8*SSA (YSZ or TiO2)). The SSA and pore volume of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst decreased slightly when compared with those of YSZ support, whereas its average pore size was nearly the same as that of YSZ. This fact could indicate that most part of Co3O4 oxide was deposed on the surface of YSZ instead of entering the pores. However, for Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst, the SSA, pore volume and average pore size showed a remarkable decline in comparison to that of the TiO2 support, which suggested a partial blockage of the pores of TiO2 by Co3O4 particles. XRD patterns of the catalysts and the corresponding supports are displayed in Fig. 1 (B). These XRD results clearly confirmed the formation of a pure spinel cubic Co3O4 phase (JCPDS file No.42-1467) in both bulk and supported catalysts. The YSZ and TiO2 supports after calcination showed a cubic structure (JCPDS file No.30-1468) and a tetragonal structure (JCPDS file No.65-5714), respectively, which were not modified during the preparation of the Co3O4-supported catalysts. Moreover, the crystallite size of bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4-supported catalysts was calculated using Scherrer’s equation based on the (311) crystal face (2θ = 36.8°), Table 1. The Co3O4 crystalline size slightly decreased for Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, whereas a significant decrease was observed for Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst, suggesting that the support could prevent the crystal growth of Co3O4 particles, as recently reported in literature for SiO2-supported CeO2 catalysts [35]. This fact could also explain the above-mentioned blockage of TiO2 pores by the cobalt ions adsorption into TiO2 support during the synthesis process. The crystallite sizes of YSZ and TiO2 in both bare oxides were also calculated using Scherrer’s equation based on the (111) crystal face (2θ = 30.1°) and (101) crystal face (2θ = 25.2°), respectively. SEM and TEM measurements were carried out to get insight into the overall morphology of the synthesized catalysts and, notably, to evaluate the Co3O4 particles distribution over the supports. Thus, a cubic Co3O4 morphology was clearly found for bulk Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 2 A), in agreement with our previous work in which a more detail analysis of morphology was reported [23]. However, this cubic morphology was no clear for Co3O4-supported catalysts, which could be probably attributed to the fact that the YSZ (Fig. 2 B) and TiO2 (Fig. 2 C) particles partially coating large spinel cobalt oxide grains. The latter hypothesis is in agreement with the submicron size of Co3O4 and nanometric diameters of the YSZ and TiO2 grains observed by low and high magnification TEM images (Fig. 2 E and F and E1 and F1, respectively). These images seem to indicate that the support modified the Co3O4 particles morphology, in which the observed Co3O4 grains are quite rough and irregular comparing to that observed for bulk Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 2 D and D1). Moreover, a comparison of the micro-metric size of the Co3O4 grains revealed by TEM with the size of the crystallites derived from XRD (87.8−45.3 nm) could also indicate that observed spinel grains are actually composed of several compacted crystallites. Nevertheless, although the spinel Co3O4 grains on both Co3O4/YSZ (Fig. 2 E, E1) and Co3O4/TiO2 (Fig. 2 F, F1) catalysts seem to be partially agglomerated, its particle size was smaller than that of the bulk Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 2 D, D1). These results are in agreement with the above-mentioned XRD measurements. To sum up, according to the XRD results, both bulk and supported catalysts exhibited a crystalline structure typical of spinel cubic Co3O4 materials, and the incorporation of YSZ and TiO2 as a support appears to have an important influence on crystal growth of Co3O4 particles. The latter hypothesis was also observed by TEM images, in which the micro-metric Co3O4 grains seem to be partially covered by the nano-metric YSZ and TiO2 grains. The morphology of Co3O4 particles was also modified by the incorporation of both supports. However, further studies should be performed to completely understand the support effect on Co3O4 morphology, including fast Fourier transform (FFT) measurements in high resolution TEM images. In addition, the reducibility of bulk Co3O4 and supported Co3O4 catalysts, a key parameter in VOCs oxidation reactions [36–38], was evaluated by H2-TPR, Fig. 3 . It is noteworthy that the catalytic oxidation of toluene proceeds through a Mars-Van Krevelen (MvK)-type of mechanism [39], including the oxidation of toluene with surface oxygen species and so, the reduction of oxidized catalyst sites by toluene, which will be further re-oxidized by gas phase oxygen to form surface oxygen species again. For that, the catalytic performances for toluene oxidation are expected to be improved through a redox ability at the lowest possible temperature. For bulk Co3O4 catalyst, two reduction peaks were clearly observed, Fig. 3. The first reduction peak centered at 324 °C was associated with the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, while the second peak located at 366 °C was assigned to the subsequent reduction of Co2+ to Co° [22]. Note that the deconvolution profiles of these first and second reduction peaks are denoted as I and II in Fig. 3. The H2-TPR analyses of the supports was also performed for comparison purpose in order to understand their reducibility and those of the supported catalysts. These results showed that TiO2 exhibited a single reduction peak at high temperature (at 470 °C) due to the partial reduction of TiO2, while YSZ displayed no obvious reduction peak in the given temperature range. Compared with bulk Co3O4 catalyst and the bare supports, obvious modifications of the onset reduction temperature, at which the reduction of Co3+ ions to Co2+ started, and as a consequence, the low-temperature reducibility were found for supported catalysts (Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts). For Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, a clear shift of the reduction temperature (reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ at 291 °C) was observed, which indicates that the synergistic effect of YSZ support promotes the reduction of Co3O4 particles. Among others, this could be related to the smaller crystallite size of Co3O4[40]. Moreover, the anionic vacancies of YSZ support can also play an important role in term of reducibility and catalytic redox cycles. Thus, some cobalt species can occupy these anionic vacancies, making them easier to be reduced, which could also explain the better reducibility of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst [41]. Therefore, the positive interaction between Co3O4 and YSZ contributed to the lower reduction temperatures observed for this supported Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, increasing its low-temperature reducibility. Further temperature-programmed oxygen isotopic exchange (TPOIE) experiments were carried out to have a better understanding of the phenomena. On the contrary, an opposite effect was observed in presence of TiO2. Two reduction peaks at 344 and 386 °C were found for Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst. The first reduction peak could be assigned to the reduction of surface oxygen and Co3+ to Co2+, whereas the second one could be attributed to not only the reduction of Co2+ but also the partial reduction of TiO2 (Ti4+ into Ti3+). The reduction peaks of Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst shifted to higher temperature compared with those of the bulk Co3O4 catalyst, even though it possessed a small Co3O4 crystallite size. This shift of reduction temperature suggests a strong interaction between cobalt oxides and TiO2 support. The cobalt oxides seem to be strongly adsorbed on the TiO2 support, which could give rise to the formation of hardily reducible sub-surface interacted Co3O4–TiO2 or CoTiO3 species [42,43], decreasing the redox ability, which could be detrimental for the oxidation of toluene since Mvk mechanism [36]. Nevertheless, this shift of the reduction temperature might also arise from a coating effect, knowing that the Co3O4 spinel grains seem to be partially covered by TiO2 particles (see Fig. 2F), which could make a more difficult reducibility. Both possible assumptions affected the reducibility of Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst in a negative way, suggesting an inhibiting effect due to the synergistic combination of Co3O4 andTiO2 support [27]. Moreover, the total theoretical and experimental H2-comsumption and the ratio of two reduction peaks’ area (ApeakⅡ / ApeakⅠ) were calculated and are presented in Table 2 . The ratio of ApeakⅡ / ApeakⅠ can give an idea about the ratio of Co2+/Co3+ in the bulk structure of the catalysts. Thus, the lowest ratio obtained for bulk Co3O4 catalyst (2.15) comparing to that of Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 supported catalysts (4.93 and 3.05, respectively) suggests that a higher amount of Co2+ species is provided by supported catalysts. Moreover, the total experimental H2-consumption of bulk Co3O4 catalyst was higher than the theoretical value, which was mainly because the surface adsorbed oxygen species and higher amount of Co3+ species consumed extra hydrogen. However, the experimental H2-consumption of supported Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts decreased when compared with the theoretical values, even considering the additional consumption of H2 by the partial reduction of TiO2 in Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst. This could be ascribed to fact that more Co2+ species are presented in these two supported catalysts than expected. The surface chemical composition of the catalysts was investigated by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). XPS analysis on Co 2p and O 1s allowed to verify the electronic and structural changes induced by TiO2 and YSZ supports on spinel-Co3O4 (Fig. 4 A and B). Thus, Co 2p spectra of the bulk and supported catalysts display two main signals at binding energy (B.E.) of ∼ 795 and 780 eV, corresponding to Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 spin-orbital peaks of Co3O4 spinel. The energy difference (∼ 15.4 eV) between these two signals is in good agreement with the values in the literature, which indicates the presence of Co3O4[20]. Since the analysis of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 provides the same chemical information, the Co 2p3/2 spectra were deconvoluted based on the fitting procedure reported by González-Prior [19] (shown in Fig. 4). The peak at B.E. of 779.1 eV was attributed to surface Co3+ species, while the peak at B.E. of 780.8 eV was assigned to surface Co2+ species. Particularly, it should be noticed that a certain amount of CoO (lower than 10% of the total amount of cobalt) was also observed in the Co 2p spectra, Fig.4 (A) of the supported catalysts, as revealed by the XPS signal at ∼ 784.5 eV [19,44]. The surface Co2+/Co3+ molar ratio was calculated and listed in Table 2, which are in good agreement with the bulk Co2+/Co3+ ratio suggested by H2-TPR results (see ratio of ApeakⅡ / ApeakⅠ). Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, unlike spinel-Co3O4, exhibit more relative tetrahedral sites occupied by Co2+, probably as a consequence of hydroxyl groups, OH− chemisorbed on vacant lattice sites. Note that these Co2+ cations are reported to be very active sites for CO, propane and toluene oxidation [20,45]. Thus, this higher surface Co2+ species could be correlated with an MvK mechanism, where the oxygen molecule adsorption takes place on an available reduced site (Co2 +-□). Fig. 4 B shows core level spectra of O1 s for bulk Co3O4, Co3O4/TiO2 and Co3O4/YSZ, respectively. The O1 s spectra, Fig.4 (B), of bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts can be fitted into two components attributable to: 1) the presence of surface lattice oxygen (Olatt.), which is identified at lower binding energy around 529.6 eV, and 2) the adsorbed oxygen at the surface oxygen vacancies and oxygen-containing group such as hydroxyl species (Oads), which is located at 531.3 eV [38,46]. The spectrum of bulk Co3O4 shows 42% of Oads and 52% of Olatt., whereas Co3O4/TiO2 exhibits 22% of Oads and 78% of Olatt.. In contrast, the spectrum of Co3O4/YSZ can be fitted into three contributions, namely Oads., Olatt. and nonstoichiometric zirconia (located at a binding energy around 528.5 eV) [47], representing 23%, 62% and 15%, respectively. Note that this nonstoichiometric zirconia may induce structural changes through bonds lengths variations concomitant with a significant amorphization of the structure. Thus, the nonstoichiometric zirconia together with oxygen vacancies could participate to the oxidation mechanism, favoring the oxygen activation and mobility, as it was reported in the literature for zirconia and ceria oxides [48,49]. The catalytic performance of bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4 supported catalysts were evaluated in the total oxidation of toluene, which acted as a model reaction for VOCs oxidation. The toluene conversion as a function of reaction temperature during the third catalytic run (cooling ramp) was showed in Fig. 5 . The values of T50 and T90 (the temperature for 50% and 90% conversion of toluene) were presented in Table 3 . The catalytic activity was enhanced in presence of YSZ as a catalytic support, which could be related to the synergistic effect of support and/or the positive interaction of cobalt oxides and YSZ support. This synergy combination seems to favor the creation of highly active sites [27]. Moreover, the presence of oxygen vacancies on YSZ support are expected to facilitate the oxygen mobility, favoring the redox cycles and improving the catalytic activity [50]. As a matter of fact, the anionic oxygen vacancies on YSZ (as well as the nonstoichiometric zirconia) could facilitate the oxygen transfer or mobility from YSZ to the catalyst surface, whose will probably participate in the oxidation reaction or improve the catalytic activity of cobalt catalyst. Furthermore, toluene conversion to CO2 over Co3O4/YSZ catalyst increased rapidly from 30% to nearly 100% from 275 to 285 °C, suggesting that an enough number of high reactive active sites are presented in this catalyst. This very steep slope was recently reported by by Y. Fang et al. [51]. Note that the CO concentration produced over Co3O4/YSZ catalyst was below 30 ppm in whole temperature range (shown in Fig. S1), which can be consider negligible, confirming the great selectivity of toluene oxidation to CO2. However, an opposite effect was observed for TiO2-supported catalyst, which showed a toluene catalytic activity even worse to that of the bulk Co3O4 catalyst. In order to verify the Co3O4 and support interaction effect, the toluene catalytic tests were also performed with a dual catalyst bed system consisting of bulk Co3O4 catalyst and YSZ or TiO2 support beds. From the profiles as well as T50 and T90, the catalytic activity of the catalysts followed the order of Co3O4/YSZ > Co3O4+SiC > Co3O4/TiO2> Co3O4+YSZ > Co3O4+TiO2. A drastically decreases of catalytic activity was produced without intimate contact, which suggests that a close interaction between Co3O4 phase and support is beneficial for toluene oxidation. Moreover, these results confirmed that the catalytic properties for toluene oxidation are highly influenced by the intrinsic properties of the support and the cobalt oxides-support interaction induced by its synergy combination. Indeed, for Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, spinel Co3O4 phase and YSZ support interact resulting in an overall effect that is greater than the sum of individual effects of any of them and/or that of dual catalyst beds. Thus, the highest catalytic activity of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst could be attributed to the synergistic effect induced by YSZ support, which helps to decrease the particle size of Co3O4 oxides and promotes the reducibility and oxygen mobility of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst. Otherwise, the higher concentration of Co2+ species and the presence of oxygen vacancies (including Oads and nonstoichiometric zirconia contribution) on the catalyst surface of Co3O4/YSZ (XPS measurements), which can participate in the reaction mechanism for oxidation of toluene, seem to improve the oxygen activation and the catalytic redox cycle and, as a consequence, the catalytic performance of this catalyst. Although the Co2+ concentration on the surface of Co3O4/TiO2 was also slightly higher than that on bulk Co3O4, the strong interaction between Co3O4 and TiO2 lead to a worse reducibility, which is unfavorable for toluene oxidation on this catalyst. Note that the coating effect can also be reason of a lower catalytic activity (less available active sites for VOC activation and oxidation). Moreover, the presence of oxygen vacancies on YSZ seems to promote the oxygen adsorption and oxygen mobility from YSZ toward the support surface, as it was early mentioned, which became highly reactive [27,52]. TPOIE experiments were carried out to better understanding of the phenomena. Nevertheless, further studies are needed to understand exactly the reaction mechanism. For this purpose, in our next study, in-situ DRIFTS experiments using labelled oxygen and kinetics modellings will be implemented. The toluene oxidation reaction rates of bulk and supported catalysts, which were calculated at 275 °C, confirmed the above-mentioned conclusions, Table 3. As expected, the supported Co3O4/YSZ catalyst exhibited the largest reaction rate (20.1 × 10−8 mol g-1 s-1) comparing to that of bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts (12.3 × 10−8 and 0.2 × 10−8 mol g-1 s-1, respectively). The Arrhenius plots for bulk Co3O4 and supported Co3O4 catalysts at less the 10% of toluene conversion are depicted in Fig. S2. The apparent activation energies (Ea) and pre-exponential factors (A) were consequently calculated from the slops of the lines and their intercepts, respectively, Table 3. The most active catalyst, Co3O4/YSZ, showed an Ea value of 191 kJ mol-1, which was similar compared with value reported in the literature for Co−CO3-3 T catalyst [53] and higher than that of Co3O4 sample S-160 [38]. The pre-exponential factors increased as the activation energies did. This unusual phenomenon could be explained by a compensation effect, as reported in the literature [40]. The catalytic stability was also evaluated by performing three consecutive catalytic runs of toluene oxidation for each catalyst. As shown in Fig. S3 (cooling ramps), reproducible results were obtained for toluene oxidation during the three consecutive runs. No appreciable deactivation was detected after three runs. Moreover, the catalytic stability in long-term test was also evaluated over Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 supported catalysts for 50 h. The corresponding profiles of toluene conversion as a function of time on stream are illustrated in Fig. 6 . It could be observed that Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts could exhibit a good catalytic durability at 280 and 365 °C, respectively. Co3O4/YSZ showed approximately 70% toluene conversion at the beginning and the conversion stayed very stable for 50 h, suggesting its potential in the practical application. Nevertheless, further experiments should be performed to verify the catalyst efficiency under real gas streams, including the presence of water vapor in the feed stream. Temperature-programmed oxygen isotopic exchange (TPOIE) experiments were performed to better understand the catalytic results and to determine the oxygen activation and mobility over bulk Co3O4, Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts. The isotopic distribution as well as the evolution of the 18O atomic fraction (αg) are presented as a function of the temperature in Fig. 7 . One can clearly see that the distribution and the temperature of exchange depend on the sample. Over bulk Co3O4 (Fig. 7A), the exchange activity started slightly below 300 °C with the appearance of 16O2 (P32) but the formation of 16O18O (P34) became rapidly predominant indicating the preponderance of the simple mechanism of the heterolytic exchange (18O2 (gaz) + 16O (s) = 16O18O (gaz) + 18O (s)). Over Co3O4/YSZ (Fig. 7B), the oxygen exchange was shifted to lower temperatures with a quick increase of the 16O2 formation from 250 °C. The formation of 16O2 on Co3O4/YSZ catalyst could be due to two successive single atom exchange mechanisms over Co3O4 and YSZ as it was previously observed over a dual bed composed of LaMnO3 and YSZ [33]. Contrary to the YSZ support, it can be seen on Fig. 7C that the TiO2 support inhibited the oxygen exchange activity with a very slow evolution of the isotopic distribution from 400 °C. The comparison is made easier with Fig. 8 in which the number of exchanged atoms (Ne) were reported for the three samples as a function of temperature. As shown in Fig. 8, the oxygen exchange of the bulk Co3O4 catalyst started at around 290 °C to reach Ne = 13.9*1020 at. g−1 at 500 °C, while the profile of Co3O4 supported on YSZ showed that oxygen exchange occurred at a lower temperature (around 250 °C) compared to that of bulk Co3O4 catalyst. Moreover, a strong increase of Ne value (43.9*1020 at. g−1 at 500 °C) for YSZ supported catalyst was obtained, which evidenced a beneficial effect due to the ionic conducting support. Contrary to Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, the oxygen exchange of Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst is delayed compared with single Co3O4 with a decrease of Ne value (10.2*1020 at. g−1 at 500ºC). Moreover, Co3O4/YSZ catalyst showed a plateau at about 400 °C, which corresponds to an equilibrium of 18O concentration between the solid and the gas phase, whereas this temperature seems to be the beginning of Co3O4/TiO2 catalyst exchange. The numbers of exchanged O atoms at 400 °C are compared in Table 4 , where it can be seen that the exchange fraction for Co3O4/YSZ catalyst corresponded to 43.3% of the total number of O atoms in the solid taking into account both Co3O4 and YSZ oxides. It is worth noting that bare TiO2 and YSZ are not able to exchange lattice O atom at 400 °C. At this temperature, only 6.2 and 0.8% of O atoms are exchanged in Co3O4 and Co3O4/TiO2 respectively. In order to highlight the synergistic effect observed for Co3O4/YSZ and the inhibiting effect in the case of Co3O4/TiO2, the mechanical mixtures was also studied (Fig. S4 and Table 4). The mechanical mixture (Co3O4+YSZ, Fig. S4A) has an intermediate behavior in between Co3O4 and Co3O4/YSZ with 18.0*1020 at. g−1 at 400 °C. It demonstrated that the interaction between Co3O4 and YSZ on Co3O4/YSZ catalyst was better than the contact obtained with a mechanical mixture to promote the activation and diffusion of oxygen. It was well known that the oxygen activation on the YSZ surface as well as their activity in catalytic oxidation started at a moderate temperature (around 500 °C). Then, it was demonstrated that the Co3O4 activated the O2 molecule on the YSZ oxygen vacancy sites, resulting in a significant increase of the oxidation rate of toluene oxidation. The curve observed for the mechanical mixture Co3O4 + TiO2 (Fig. S4B) was close to the curve monitored for single Co3O4 with the same fraction of exchanged atoms at 400 °C (6.2 and 6.3% for Co3O4 and Co3O4 + TiO2, respectively). This inhibiting effect is therefore specific of the TiO2-supported Co3O4 catalyst. This fact could be attributed to the strong adsorption of cobalt oxides on the lattice oxygen of TiO2 as well as to the support coating effect, avoiding the ability to oxygen exchange. This behavior could also explain the high reduction temperature needed to reduce the cobalt species previously archived by H2-TPR experiment (Fig. 3). Thus, the decrease of toluene oxidation efficiency of Co3O4/TiO2 supported catalyst (Fig. 5) could be related to the decrease of reducibility and oxygen mobility induced by the partial coating of the cobalt oxide by titanium oxide, which can block some of the active cobalt sites reflecting in a lower activity. Finally, a comparison between the catalytic performance of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst and those of supported Co3O4 or noble metal catalysts that have been reported in the literatures is displayed in Table 5 . The performance of Co3O4/YSZ was better than 15 wt.% Co/γ-Al2O3[54], Co3O4/ZSM-5 [46], Co3O4/SBA-15 [46] and Au/TiO2[46], similar to those of Co3O4/Beta [46] and Pd/SBA-15 [46] catalysts and worse than that of the Co3O4/CNTs-120 [46], Au/CeO2[25] and Pt/TiNT [55] catalysts. 4 Conclusions The synergistic effect between spinel Co3O4 oxides and YSZ or TiO2 supports on total oxidation of toluene was evaluated. For this propose, bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4 supported catalysts were synthetized by one-step hydrothermal preparation method. Obtained results showed that both physicochemical and catalytic properties were significantly modified by the support. Co3O4 oxides appeared to interact with TiO2 and YSZ. These interactions affected the toluene catalytic activity in a positive way for the Co3O4/YSZ catalyst, while TiO2 catalyst showed an opposite effect, even worse to that of the bulk Co3O4 catalyst. The low-temperature reducibility, oxygen activation and mobility of Co3O4/YSZ catalyst were promoted by the synergy combination of Co3O4 phase and YSZ support, according to H2-TPR and isotopic exchange measurements. Indeed, the Co3O4 phase seems to activate the O2 molecule on YSZ oxygen vacancy sites, resulting in a significant increase of the oxidation rate of toluene oxidation. On the contrary, the strong adsorption of Co3O4 on the TiO2 support and/or the possible coating effect seem to decrease the catalyst reducibility and avoid the ability to oxygen activation and mobility. Moreover, the synergistic effect induced by YSZ support was corroborated by testing a dual catalyst bed system consisting of bulk Co3O4 catalyst and YSZ support beds. The expected additive effect of said was lower than that of Co3O4 oxides and YSZ support working in intimate combination. coredata.dc:description: Bulk spinel Co3O4 oxide and supported Co3O4 catalysts (Co3O4/YSZ and Co3O4/TiO2) were synthesized by one-step hydrothermal method. Their physicochemical properties were characterized by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy, N2-sorption, powder X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy.These characterization strategies were applied to corroborate and better understand the interaction between Co3O4 and the supports induced by the synergistic effect of support and the subsequent catalytic performance in toluene oxidation. The catalytic stability was evaluated by three consecutive runs and a long-term test. A highest toluene catalytic activity was achieved over Co3O4/YSZ supported catalyst comparing to that of the bulk Co3O4 and Co3O4/TiO2 catalysts, which could be attributed to its better low-temperature reducibility, oxygen activation and mobility induced by the intrinsic support properties. Thus, the positive interaction between spinel Co3O4 phase and YSZ support promoted the intrinsic catalytic properties for toluene oxidation, which was verify by testing a dual catalyst bed system consisting of bulk Co3O4 catalyst and YSZ support beds. These results were further confirmed by temperature-programmed oxygen isotopic exchange experiments, which indicated that the activation and diffusion of oxygen species on the YSZ oxygen vacancy sites were promoted by Co3O4, resulting in a significant increase of the reaction rate for toluene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Spinel Co3O4 oxides-support synergistic effect on catalytic oxidation of toluene
